author: potuz
content: I spent some time today trying to understand how come some test vectors ssz for bitlists were a couple of bytes larger than the raw value. Until I realized that it was snappy that is not good with random bitlists... I guess the only way of getting used to these things is to get our hands dirty and code

author: protolambda
content: <@!755590043632140352> Bitlists also contain a delimiter bit. The decoding "scope" is in bytes, so to determine the length in bits, an extra trailing bit is added to delimit the length. And so when you have a bitlist of a multiple of 8 bits in length, the delimit bit pushes the scope to one more byte.

author: potuz
content: Yeah I know, that's why I was surprised to see **two bytes**. Anyway this happened on an example with 31 bits, and it was because snappy is not useful in these small and random cases
